name: Sputnik 1
detail: First artificial Earth satellite, launched by the Soviet Union. Transmitted radio signals for 22 days and orbited for 3 months before atmospheric reentry.

name: Sputnik 2
detail: Carried Laika, a dog, becoming the first spacecraft to carry a living animal into orbit. Proved biological cargo could survive launch and weightlessness.

name: Explorer 1
detail: First U.S. satellite, discovered the Van Allen radiation belts. Launched on a Juno I rocket from Cape Canaveral.

name: Vanguard 1
detail: Fourth artificial satellite launched, oldest satellite still in orbit. Provided data on Earth's shape and upper atmospheric density.

name: Luna 1
detail: First spacecraft to reach escape velocity from Earth and fly by the Moon. Detected solar wind and measured radiation belts.

name: Luna 2
detail: First spacecraft to impact the Moon, striking the surface east of Mare Serenitatis. Confirmed the Moon has no magnetic field.

name: Luna 3
detail: First spacecraft to photograph the far side of the Moon. Revealed mountainous terrain and few maria on the lunar far side.

name: TIROS-1
detail: First successful weather satellite, transmitted 22,952 photos of Earth's cloud cover. Proved viability of monitoring weather from space.

name: Echo 1
detail: First passive communications satellite, a 100-foot diameter metalized balloon that reflected radio signals between ground stations.

name: Vostok 1
detail: Yuri Gagarin became the first human in space, completing one orbit of Earth in 108 minutes. Historic achievement for human spaceflight.

name: Mercury-Redstone 3
detail: Alan Shepard became the first American in space on a 15-minute suborbital flight reaching 116 miles altitude.

name: Mercury-Redstone 4
detail: Gus Grissom's suborbital flight. Capsule Liberty Bell 7 sank after splashdown when hatch prematurely opened, recovered in 1999.

name: Vostok 2
detail: Gherman Titov spent over 25 hours in space, completing 17 orbits. First person to sleep in space and experience space sickness.

name: Mercury-Atlas 6
detail: John Glenn became the first American to orbit Earth, completing three orbits in Friendship 7. National hero's welcome upon return.

name: Mercury-Atlas 7
detail: Scott Carpenter's three-orbit mission in Aurora 7. Overshot landing zone by 250 miles due to manual control issues.

name: Telstar 1
detail: First active communications satellite to relay television signals across the Atlantic. Enabled first live transatlantic TV broadcast.

name: Vostok 3
detail: Andriyan Nikolayev orbited Earth 64 times. Part of first group spaceflight mission with Vostok 4, coming within 6.5 km.

name: Vostok 4
detail: Pavel Popovich in first dual spaceflight with Vostok 3. Completed 48 orbits, demonstrating radio communication between spacecraft.

name: Mariner 2
detail: First successful interplanetary spacecraft. Flew by Venus at 34,773 km, measuring temperature and discovering solar wind.

name: Mercury-Atlas 8
detail: Wally Schirra completed six orbits in Sigma 7, demonstrating precise spacecraft control and fuel conservation techniques.

name: Mercury-Atlas 9
detail: Gordon Cooper's 22-orbit mission in Faith 7, final Mercury flight. Longest U.S. solo spaceflight until Skylab.

name: Vostok 5
detail: Valery Bykovsky's record-setting 5-day solo flight, 81 orbits. Record stood until Soyuz 9 in 1970.

name: Vostok 6
detail: Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space, completing 48 orbits. Remains only woman to fly solo space mission.

name: Syncom 3
detail: First geostationary satellite, positioned over the International Date Line. Broadcast 1964 Tokyo Olympics worldwide.

name: Voskhod 1
detail: First multi-person crew (3 cosmonauts). Vladimir Komarov, Konstantin Feoktistov, Boris Yegorov completed 16 orbits.

name: Mariner 4
detail: First spacecraft to fly by Mars, returning 22 close-up photos revealing cratered surface. Changed understanding of Mars.

name: Voskhod 2
detail: Alexei Leonov performed first spacewalk (EVA), 12 minutes outside spacecraft. Pavel Belyayev piloted. Faced near-fatal reentry issues.

name: Gemini 3
detail: First crewed Gemini mission. Gus Grissom and John Young completed 3 orbits, testing manual maneuvers and orbit changes.

name: Gemini 4
detail: Ed White performed America's first spacewalk, 23 minutes. James McDivitt commanded 4-day mission with 62 orbits.

name: Gemini 5
detail: Gordon Cooper and Charles Conrad completed 8-day endurance mission, 120 orbits. Proved human capability for lunar mission duration.

name: Gemini 7
detail: Frank Borman and Jim Lovell's 14-day endurance mission. Rendezvous target for Gemini 6A, coming within 1 foot.

name: Gemini 6A
detail: Wally Schirra and Tom Stafford achieved first space rendezvous with Gemini 7. Station-kept for over 5 hours.

name: Gemini 8
detail: Neil Armstrong and David Scott achieved first docking in space with Agena target. Emergency abort due to thruster malfunction.

name: Gemini 9A
detail: Tom Stafford and Gene Cernan. Rendezvous but couldn't dock due to shroud failure. Cernan's 2-hour EVA exhausting.

name: Gemini 10
detail: John Young and Michael Collins rendezvoused with two Agena targets. Collins performed standup and umbilical EVAs.

name: Gemini 11
detail: Pete Conrad and Dick Gordon achieved first-orbit rendezvous, reached record altitude of 1,369 km using Agena propulsion.

name: Gemini 12
detail: Final Gemini mission. Jim Lovell and Buzz Aldrin perfected EVA techniques with 5.5 hours outside, proving viability for Apollo.

name: Apollo 1
detail: Tragedy: Gus Grissom, Ed White, Roger Chaffee killed in command module fire during ground test. Led to major spacecraft redesign.

name: Apollo 4
detail: First uncrewed test of Saturn V rocket. Successful demonstration of launch vehicle and command module heat shield.

name: Apollo 7
detail: First crewed Apollo mission. Wally Schirra, Donn Eisele, Walter Cunningham completed 11-day Earth orbit shakedown, 163 orbits.

name: Apollo 8
detail: First crewed mission to Moon. Frank Borman, Jim Lovell, Bill Anders orbited Moon 10 times, Earthrise photo, Christmas Eve broadcast.

name: Apollo 9
detail: First crewed test of Lunar Module in Earth orbit. Jim McDivitt, Dave Scott, Rusty Schweickart. 10-day mission testing rendezvous.

name: Apollo 10
detail: Dress rehearsal for landing. Tom Stafford, John Young, Gene Cernan. LM descended to 15.6 km above Moon, fastest humans ever.

name: Apollo 11
detail: First lunar landing. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on Moon while Michael Collins orbited. 'That's one small step for man...'

name: Apollo 12
detail: Pete Conrad and Alan Bean landed in Ocean of Storms, pinpoint landing near Surveyor 3. Dick Gordon orbited. Lightning struck at launch.

name: Apollo 13
detail: 'Houston, we've had a problem.' Oxygen tank explosion aborted landing. Jim Lovell, Jack Swigert, Fred Haise survived harrowing return.

name: Venera 7
detail: First spacecraft to successfully transmit data from another planet's surface, Venus. Survived 475°C heat for 23 minutes.

name: Apollo 14
detail: Alan Shepard and Ed Mitchell landed in Fra Mauro highlands. Shepard hit golf balls on Moon. Stuart Roosa orbited.

name: Salyut 1
detail: First space station. Soyuz 11 crew spent 23 days aboard but died during reentry due to valve failure.

name: Mars 3
detail: First spacecraft to soft-land on Mars. Lander transmitted for 14.5 seconds before contact lost. Orbiter operated 8 months.

name: Mariner 9
detail: First spacecraft to orbit another planet. Mapped 85% of Mars, discovered Olympus Mons and Valles Marineris.

name: Apollo 15
detail: First J-mission with Lunar Roving Vehicle. Dave Scott and Jim Irwin explored Hadley Rille. Al Worden orbited, conducted deep-space EVA.

name: Pioneer 10
detail: First spacecraft through asteroid belt and to Jupiter. Carries plaque for extraterrestrials. Left solar system in 1983.

name: Apollo 16
detail: John Young and Charlie Duke explored Descartes Highlands with rover. Ken Mattingly orbited. Lunar UV astronomy experiments.

name: Apollo 17
detail: Final Apollo lunar mission. Gene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt (geologist) explored Taurus-Littrow. Ron Evans orbited. Last humans beyond LEO.

name: Pioneer 11
detail: Studied Jupiter then first to Saturn, discovered F-ring. Used Jupiter gravity assist. Left solar system in 1990.

name: Skylab
detail: America's first space station. Damaged during launch but repaired by crew. Hosted three crews totaling 171 days.

name: Skylab 2
detail: First Skylab crew. Pete Conrad, Joe Kerwin, Paul Weitz deployed sunshade to save station, spent 28 days conducting experiments.

name: Skylab 3
detail: Alan Bean, Jack Lousma, Owen Garriott spent 59 days aboard Skylab. Extensive solar astronomy and Earth observations.

name: Mariner 10
detail: First spacecraft to Mercury via Venus gravity assist. Mapped 45% of Mercury in three flybys. Pioneered gravity assist technique.

name: Skylab 4
detail: Final Skylab crew. Jerry Carr, Ed Gibson, Bill Pogue spent 84 days, record until Salyut. Observed Comet Kohoutek.

name: Apollo-Soyuz Test Project
detail: First international space rendezvous. Tom Stafford, Vance Brand, Deke Slayton docked with Alexei Leonov and Valery Kubasov's Soyuz 19.

name: Viking 1
detail: First successful Mars landing. Operated 6 years on surface, orbiter for 4. Searched for life, found none conclusively.

name: Viking 2
detail: Second successful Mars lander, touched down in Utopia Planitia. Operated nearly 4 years, complemented Viking 1 data.

name: Voyager 2
detail: Only spacecraft to visit Uranus and Neptune. Grand Tour of outer planets. Entered interstellar space 2018.

name: Voyager 1
detail: Explored Jupiter and Saturn. Now in interstellar space, farthest human-made object. Carries Golden Record for aliens.

name: STS-1
detail: First Space Shuttle mission. John Young and Bob Crippen aboard Columbia tested reusable spacecraft for 54 hours, 36 orbits.

name: STS-5
detail: First operational Shuttle mission. Vance Brand commanded Columbia, deployed two commercial satellites. First 4-person crew.

name: STS-7
detail: Sally Ride became first American woman in space aboard Challenger. Deployed satellites, operated SPAS-01 free-flyer.

name: STS-41-B
detail: Bruce McCandless performed first untethered spacewalk using Manned Maneuvering Unit. 'I may be a malfunctioning satellite, but I'm having a great time!'

name: STS-51-L
detail: Challenger disaster. Crew of 7 including teacher Christa McAuliffe killed 73 seconds after launch due to O-ring failure in cold weather.

name: Mir Core Module
detail: Soviet/Russian space station core. Continuously inhabited 1989-1999. Hosted international crews including Americans.

name: STS-26
detail: Return to Flight after Challenger. Discovery mission commanded by Rick Hauck deployed TDRS satellite. Successful 4-day mission.

name: Magellan
detail: Mapped 98% of Venus surface with synthetic aperture radar from STS-30 Atlantis. Operated until 1994 when deliberately crashed.

name: Galileo
detail: Orbited Jupiter 1995-2003. Discovered subsurface ocean on Europa, observed Shoemaker-Levy 9 impact. Deployed from STS-34 Atlantis.

name: STS-31
detail: Discovery deployed Hubble Space Telescope. Loren Shriver commanded. HST revolutionized astronomy despite initial mirror flaw.

name: STS-61
detail: Hubble repair mission. Dick Covey commanded Endeavour. Five EVAs installed corrective optics (COSTAR), new solar arrays. Saved HST.

name: STS-71
detail: First Shuttle-Mir docking. Atlantis delivered Norm Thagard home after 115 days on Mir. Began Shuttle-Mir program cooperation.

name: Mars Global Surveyor
detail: Mapped entire Martian surface in unprecedented detail. Operated until 2006. Confirmed past liquid water evidence.

name: Mars Pathfinder
detail: Landed on Mars with Sojourner rover, first wheeled vehicle on another planet. Operated 83 sols, vastly exceeded mission goals.

name: Cassini-Huygens
detail: Orbited Saturn 2004-2017. Huygens probe landed on Titan. Discovered methane lakes, geysers on Enceladus. Grand finale into Saturn.

name: Deep Space 1
detail: Tested ion propulsion engine, autonomous navigation, and other technologies. Flew by asteroid Braille and comet Borrelly.

name: ISS Zarya
detail: First ISS module launched by Russia. Provided power and propulsion initially. Foundation of International Space Station.

name: STS-88
detail: Endeavour attached Unity node to Zarya, beginning ISS assembly. Bob Cabana commanded first ISS assembly flight.

name: Stardust
detail: Collected comet Wild 2 samples and returned to Earth 2006. First sample return from beyond Moon, brought pristine interstellar dust.

name: ISS Expedition 1
detail: First permanent ISS crew. Bill Shepherd, Yuri Gidzenko, Sergei Krikalev arrived on Soyuz TM-31. Continuous habitation began.

name: STS-98
detail: Atlantis delivered Destiny Laboratory Module to ISS. Ken Cockrell commanded. US science hub with 24 equipment racks.

name: Genesis
detail: Collected solar wind particles. Sample return capsule crash-landed 2004 but some samples recovered for analysis of Sun's composition.

name: STS-107
detail: Columbia disaster. Crew of 7 killed during reentry when wing damage from foam strike caused breakup. Led to Shuttle retirement decision.

name: MER Spirit
detail: Mars Exploration Rover landed in Gusev Crater. Planned 90 sols, operated over 2200 sols until 2010. Found evidence of ancient water.

name: MER Opportunity
detail: Mars rover landed in Meridiani Planum. Operated 14+ years, traveled 45 km. Discovered hematite spheres 'blueberries', lost in dust storm 2018.

name: MESSENGER
detail: First spacecraft to orbit Mercury. Mapped entire planet, discovered water ice at poles, measured magnetic field. Crashed into Mercury 2015.

name: STS-114
detail: Return to Flight after Columbia. Discovery commanded by Eileen Collins. New safety procedures, external tank cameras, inspection boom.

name: Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter
detail: High-resolution imaging of Mars surface. HiRISE camera sees objects as small as 30cm. Still operational, supports rover missions.

name: New Horizons
detail: First mission to Pluto, flyby 2015 revealed heart-shaped nitrogen glacier. Continued to Kuiper Belt object Arrokoth in 2019.

name: Phoenix
detail: Landed near Mars north pole, confirmed water ice just below surface. 'Followed the water' strategy vindicated. Operated 5 months.

name: STS-123
detail: Endeavour delivered Japanese Kibo logistics module and Dextre robotic manipulator. Dominic Gorie commanded. ISS expansion continued.

name: STS-124
detail: Discovery delivered Japanese Kibo pressurized module, largest ISS component. Mark Kelly commanded. Japan's primary ISS laboratory.

name: SpaceX Falcon 1 Flight 4
detail: First privately developed liquid-fuel rocket to reach orbit. Fourth attempt successful. Carried dummy payload, proved SpaceX viability.

name: STS-126
detail: Endeavour delivered equipment to expand ISS crew from 3 to 6. Chris Ferguson commanded. Water recycling system for permanent 6-person ops.

name: Kepler
detail: Discovered 2,662 exoplanets by transit method. Proved planets are common in galaxy. Operated until 2018 when fuel exhausted.

name: STS-125
detail: Final Hubble servicing mission. Atlantis crew performed 5 EVAs installing Wide Field Camera 3 and Cosmic Origins Spectrograph. Scott Altman commanded.

name: SpaceX Dragon COTS-1
detail: First commercial spacecraft to be recovered from orbit. Dragon capsule completed two orbits, splashed down in Pacific.

name: STS-135
detail: Final Space Shuttle mission. Atlantis delivered supplies to ISS. Chris Ferguson commanded. End of 30-year Shuttle program.

name: Juno
detail: Orbiting Jupiter since 2016, studying composition, gravity, magnetic field, polar magnetosphere. Solar-powered at Jupiter distance.

name: Tiangong-1
detail: China's first space station prototype. Hosted two crews (Shenzhou 9 and 10). Uncontrolled reentry over Pacific 2018.

name: Curiosity/MSL
detail: Car-sized rover landed via skycrane in Gale Crater. Confirmed ancient habitability. Still exploring, climbing Mount Sharp.

name: SpaceX CRS-1
detail: First commercial resupply mission to ISS. Dragon delivered 400kg cargo. Began regular commercial cargo services.

name: Orbital Cygnus Demo
detail: First Cygnus spacecraft to ISS. Orbital Sciences (now Northrop Grumman) demonstration mission. Second commercial cargo provider.

name: MAVEN
detail: Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution mission studies how Mars lost its atmosphere. Still operational, provides communications relay.

name: Falcon 9 ORBCOMM-2
detail: First orbital-class rocket landing. SpaceX Falcon 9 first stage returned to Landing Zone 1 at Cape Canaveral. Reusability breakthrough.

name: OSIRIS-REx
detail: Collected sample from asteroid Bennu, returned to Earth 2023. Sample reveals organic molecules and water-bearing clays.

name: Tiangong-2
detail: China's second space station. Hosted Shenzhou 11 crew for 30 days. Technology testbed for permanent station. Controlled deorbit 2019.

name: Falcon Heavy Demo
detail: Most powerful operational rocket. Launched Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster toward Mars orbit. Two side boosters landed simultaneously.

name: InSight
detail: Mars lander studied interior structure with seismometer. Detected hundreds of marsquakes. Operated until late 2022, dust-covered panels.

name: Parker Solar Probe
detail: Fastest human-made object, diving through Sun's corona. Closest approach 6.1 million km from Sun. Studying solar wind origins.

name: Crew Dragon Demo-1
detail: Uncrewed test flight of SpaceX Crew Dragon to ISS. Carried Ripley test dummy. Successful docking and return paved way for crewed flights.

name: Crew Dragon Demo-2
detail: First crewed orbital spaceflight from US since 2011. Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken to ISS. Commercial crew era began.

name: Perseverance/Ingenuity
detail: Mars 2020 rover landed in Jezero Crater. Ingenuity helicopter achieved first powered flight on another planet. Collecting samples for future return.

name: Tianhe
detail: Core module of China Space Station. Permanently inhabited since June 2022. Foundation for China's modular space station.

name: Inspiration4
detail: First all-civilian orbital spaceflight. Jared Isaacman, Hayley Arceneaux, Chris Sembroski, Sian Proctor spent 3 days in orbit at 585 km altitude.

name: Lucy
detail: First mission to Jupiter Trojan asteroids. Will visit 8 asteroids over 12 years. Studying remnants from early solar system formation.

name: DART
detail: Double Asteroid Redirection Test intentionally crashed into Dimorphos moon, changing its orbit. Proved planetary defense technique viable.

name: James Webb Space Telescope
detail: Largest space telescope, observing in infrared from L2. Studying first galaxies, exoplanet atmospheres, star formation. Revolutionary science.

name: Boeing Starliner OFT-2
detail: Second uncrewed test flight of Boeing Starliner to ISS. Successfully docked after OFT-1 issues. Paved way for crewed flights.

name: Artemis I
detail: Uncrewed test flight of SLS and Orion spacecraft. 25.5-day mission orbited Moon, tested heat shield at lunar return velocity.

name: Starship IFT-1
detail: First integrated flight test of SpaceX Starship. Largest rocket ever flown. Vehicle lost during ascent but provided valuable test data.

name: Psyche
detail: Mission to metal-rich asteroid 16 Psyche. May be exposed core of early planet. Testing Deep Space Optical Communications en route.

name: Starship IFT-4
detail: Fourth Starship test. First successful soft splashdown of both stages. Super Heavy booster survived reentry and ocean landing. Major milestone.

name: Europa Clipper
detail: Orbiting Jupiter to study Europa's subsurface ocean. 49 close flybys investigating habitability of ice moon. Arrival 2030.

name: Starship IFT-6
detail: Sixth Starship test. Attempted first catch of Super Heavy booster with launch tower 'chopsticks' but aborted to ocean. Ship splashdown successful.

name: Artemis II
detail: First crewed Artemis mission. Four astronauts on lunar flyby trajectory. Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, Jeremy Hansen.
